daily-cryptic.definition: reason clock stops working / american’s holidays
daily-cryptic.solution:
SPRING BREAKS
The cryptic intro got me to the answer. Although its meaning is self-explanatory I wouldn’t have considered ‘spring break’ as a lexical term, but my AI assistant now renamed Gemini advises: ‘Spring break’ in America is a time-honoured tradition for students, a week-long escape from classes and exams. It typically falls between March and April.

STREET
STET (ignore this) containing [covering] RE (on). ‘Stet’ is a typographical instruction to cancel a correction or deletion.  Literally it means ‘let it stand’.

daily-cryptic.clue: Eros perhaps appearing centrally in last item from Aida (8)

ASTEROID
{l}AS{t} + {i}TE{m} + {f}RO{m} + {a}ID{a} [centrally]

daily-cryptic.clue: Initially, hard to oust female feeling a certain desire (7)
daily-cryptic.solution:
ATHIRST
AT fIRST (initially) becomes ATHIRST when H (hard) replaces [to oust] f (female). Figuratively this can refer to any longing, not just for liquid refreshment.

daily-cryptic.clue: Step out of a prison (4)
daily-cryptic.solution: STIR – STAIR (step) – (out of) A

daily-cryptic.clue: Ravel’s penned unusual Slav or Czech nationalist work (2,5)
daily-cryptic.solution:
MÁ VLAST
MAT (ravel – entangle) contains (’s penned) anagram [unusual] of SLAV. This is a series of 6 tone poems by the Czech composer, Smetana. The title translates as ‘My country / homeland’ hence ‘nationalist’ in the definition. Probably the most famous of the pieces is Vltava aka The Moldau which depicts the course of ‘the Czech national river’ from its source to its confluence with the Elbe.
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 29048 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Moving supply of things for reading by ambassador (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: LITHE – LIT (literature, things for reading) + HE (His Excellency, ambassador). Supple-y!

daily-cryptic.clue: Junior officer’s quarters good for stopping crime (6)

ENSIGN
E + N (quarters), then G (good) contained by [stopping] SIN (crime)

daily-cryptic.clue: Companion always providing festive fare (5)

WIDTH

daily-cryptic.title: Times 28948 – international learning – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: OUTGOINGS – OUTGOING +S, with a rather loose literal.

daily-cryptic.clue: Jazz fan, in bed, lifted by ace composition (7)

TOCCATA

daily-cryptic.clue: Engineers text covering one cathedral (5)

daily-cryptic.title: 29014 Nothing to get stuck on – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Drop  a trail of blood? (7)
daily-cryptic.solution: DESCENT – I took a while to see how this works. I think it’s a double definition, the second being descent in the sense of bloodline, heredity.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28947 – erudite, or what? – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Girl accommodating six in French farmhouse (5)
daily-cryptic.solution:
MAVIS
MAS (French farmhouse) containing [accommodating] VI (six). I had no idea what was going on here as my first port of call, Collins, doesn’t list ‘mas’, nor do the one-volume Oxfords. It’s in SOED and Chambers but the amount of foreign words not really incorporated to English that we are expected to know these days is starting to get a bit much. Also I wonder when there was last a Mavis who might reasonably have laid claim to being a girl.

daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic No 29045 — A solid performance – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Return googly but not wide “beamer” (8,3)
daily-cryptic.solution: ELECTRON GUN – this has to be one of the most obscure clues, both in terms of parsing and definition, that I’ve ever seen. It might be okay in the Mephisto. ELECT = return, “googly” is a cricketing term for a left arm bowler’s leg-break which isn’t a leg-break but turns the opposite way, also informally known as a “WRONG-UN”, (EDIT apologies, as pointed out below by ulaca, it is a right-arm leg break bowler’s wrong-un, not left-arm) then we drop the W for wide. And the mental jump from “beamer” to “electron gun”, which probably only physicists have heard of, is a bit ridiculous IMO.

daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic No 28901 — Not a snooze – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Reserved protégé knocked over in pub (6) – enumeration error, this should read (7)
daily-cryptic.solution:
INDRAWN
WARD (protégé) reversed [knocked over] and contained by [in] INN (pub). Not a word I was aware of but its meaning seems obvious enough. I note that the enumeration error also appears in the e-paper, so presumably it’s in the printed edition too.
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28838 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Show one off that’s attached to heel in blizzards? (8)
daily-cryptic.definition: show one off that’s attached to heel in blizzards
daily-cryptic.solution: SNOWSHOE – anagram of SHOW,ONE after the last letter in blizzardS
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29008 – the return of Tricky Thursday – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Cunning fellows housed in suitable accommodation (9)
daily-cryptic.solution: APARTMENT – ART(cunning) and MEN(fellows) inside APT(suitable)
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28852 – February bonus – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Gladly, no longer said to be supporting small local party (4,4)
daily-cryptic.solution:
SINN FEIN
S (small), INN (local), then aural wordplay [said] FEIN  / “fain” (gladly, no longer – archaism). More obscurity, but I was helped by a question on The Chase last Friday (the TV quiz referred to in last Thursday’s 15×15):  Is ‘Fain’ is an archaic word for (a) Gladly  (b) Bitterly,  or (c) Sadly?
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 29072 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Recommends a party including very small titbits? (9)
daily-cryptic.solution: ADVOCATES – A D(V)O + CATES.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28951 – I don’t know, I’ll ask her! – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Fish that is lacking tail (4)
daily-cryptic.solution: IDES – Fish here is plural; ID EST is Latin for that is, normally abbr. to i.e., and IDE is a fish found in crosswords and fresh water.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28857 – hence the penguin. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Severe police officer removed from locality (6)
daily-cryptic.solution:
STRICT
{di}STRICT (locality) [police officer – DI – removed]
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28892 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Earlier, a shot in court (9)
daily-cryptic.solution:
AFOREHAND
A, FOREHAND (shot in court – tennis etc)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28952 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: I’m obliged to weed lake (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: TAHOE – TA (thanks, I’m obliged) + HOE (to weed).
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28847 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Case cracked: 500 held by French city authority (10)
daily-cryptic.solution: ASCENDANCY — CASE anagrammed (cracked) + D (500) inside (held by) NANCY (French city)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28957 – some might say you lack a blogger – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Giving an example of an Arab with a very conceited attitude (8)
daily-cryptic.solution: EGOMANIA –  E.G. (giving an example), OMANI (an Arab), A.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28875 – below the snow line. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Charitable payment to the sick reduced to small coin (10)
daily-cryptic.solution:
BENEFICENT
BENEFI{t} (payment to the sick) [reduced], CENT (small coin)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28946 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Stop working   to steal (5,3)
daily-cryptic.solution: KNOCK OFF – double definition.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28815 – when January went dry. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: A setter’s offspring, might one say? (3)
daily-cryptic.solution: SUN — Sounds like (… might one say?) SON (offspring)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28957 – some might say you lack a blogger – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: People given messages, possibly sadder notices (10)
daily-cryptic.solution: ADDRESSEES – An anagram (possibly) of SADDER plus SEES for notices.
daily-cryptic.title: 28882 A (very) late message? – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Resentment in club: first couple missing for days! (7)
daily-cryptic.solution: DUDGEON – I think this is BLUDGEON for club with its first two (letters) missing and replaced by D(ays). Given the plural days, you can spend time puzzling how to replace two of something with Ds and end up with a U in the middle.
daily-cryptic.title: 28978 A lying POTUS. Imagine that! – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Lacking enthusiasm, quietly stops revolutionary eating plan (5)
daily-cryptic.solution:
TEPID
P (quietly) is contained by [stops] DIET (eating plan) reversed [revolutionary]
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28814 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: I paper over stage with wings (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: IMAGO – Technically the adult stage of an insect’s life. I, MAG for paper, O(ver).
daily-cryptic.title: 28822  Curriculum Vitae – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: One may have a reservation in diner, out to lunch with a maniac (8,6)
daily-cryptic.solution: AMERICAN INDIAN – anagram of IN,DINER and A, MANIAC. Maybe not the most politically correct clue…
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28816 – a non-cartesian pangram – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: A respectable, short debtor’s note ultimately proves damaging (10)
daily-cryptic.solution:
PERNICIOUS
PER (a), NIC{e} (respectable) [short], IOU (debtor’s note), {prove}S [ultimately]
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28940 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Ruler in crown drinking last drop of Barolo wine (9)
daily-cryptic.solution:
POTENTATE
PATE (crown) containing [drinking] {barl}O [last drop of] + TENT (wine)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28940 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Scandinavian girl at back of horse — seated thus? (7)
daily-cryptic.solution:
ASTRIDE
ASTRID (Scandinavian girl), {hors}E [at back of…]. The definition refers back to ‘horse’ in the wordplay.
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 29012 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Complain about resistance one’s seen on line (7)
daily-cryptic.solution: RAILCAR – RAIL is to complain, then C[irc]A, about and R[esistance]
daily-cryptic.title: 28858  Après Mao. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Emergency flight served by express elevator (7)
daily-cryptic.solution:
AIRLIFT
AIR (express e.g. an opinion), LIFT (elevator)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 29042 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Kuwait’s capital Arabs are changing old settlement (5,4)
daily-cryptic.solution: SKARA BRAE – anagram* of Kuwait ARABS ARE. A site on Mainland Orkney. I have spent many happy weeks on Gairsay, one of the smallest inhabitated isles in the UK.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28993 – Just like riding a bicycle – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Calling social worker to meet reticent person (7)
daily-cryptic.solution: CLAMANT – CLAM + ANT, giving a word that some solvers may not know.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28807 – On to Constance….. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Sound of jeers in court session (5-2)
daily-cryptic.solution: BOOZE-UP -BOOZE sounds like BOOS, UP as in “in court”.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29043 – stretched to the limit – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Grave tribute on air for broadcasting chief (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: REITH – sounds like WREATH. This diverted me to read about Lord Reith on Wikipedia, which was an illuminating ten minutes.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29025 – what breed of dog did you say? – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Bishop’s keeping top off, displaying muscle (6)
daily-cryptic.solution: BICEPS – At the moment, the best I can see is using BP’S as abbr. for bishop’s, inserting ICE for top off, as in ice a cake. But I’m still thinking. I prefer B’S for bishop’s which leaves ICEP to explain.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29085 – being considered, indeed. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Wood turned this way? Odd bits discarded (3)
daily-cryptic.solution: ASH – Reversed alternate letters of tHiS wAy.
daily-cryptic.title: 28942  Our survey says: completed at a cantur – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Director finished with lists completely (4,4,5)
daily-cryptic.solution: HEAD OVER HEELS – HEAD (director), OVER (finished) HEELS (lists).
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28899 – gardener’s world. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Spread around centre of Croatian seaside resort (7)
daily-cryptic.solution: MARGATE – MARG[ARIN]E is your spread, and AT from the centre of CroATian to be included. Any excuse for Chas and Dave
daily-cryptic.title: 28894  Cum On Feel the Noize – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Doing something with unwelcome intruders? (8)
daily-cryptic.solution: OCCUPIED – double definition / cryptic hint.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28997 – scotch’d the snake, not kill’d it – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Governess around isle was a wine producer (12)
daily-cryptic.solution: MADEMOISELLE – MADE MO(I)SELLE, not the first word you would think of for governess, but reasonable.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29035 – Department of tricky literals – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Finally without appeal, he had paid a percentage (6)
daily-cryptic.solution: TITHED – [withou]T + IT + HE’D.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28975 – Yes, it’s my turn! – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Popular youngster primarily interpreting nightmares (6)
daily-cryptic.solution: INCUBI – IN CUB Interpreting
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29029 – Manic Monday – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Storm passing over northern mountains (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: RANGE – N inside RAGE = storm.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29013 – I’m passing it again – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Producer of fibre products is altering bags (5)
daily-cryptic.solution:
SISAL
{product}S IS AL{tering} hides [bags] the answer
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 29060 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Allowed to remove cap that’s dreadful (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: AWFUL – lAWFUL

daily-cryptic.clue: Idiotic Head of Accounts is retiring before watershed? (7)
daily-cryptic.solution: ASININE -first of Accounts + reversal of IS + NINE (o’clock, watershed).
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29027 – more Crab than Speed – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: I happen to be drawn in by whisky and choice steak (3,3)
daily-cryptic.solution:
RIB EYE – I BE in RYE

Happen = BE? I guess, like, “Where will the event happen/be?”, or something.
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic No 29081 — I guess that’s a thing – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: VICTORIA FALLS – (CALL FOR A VISIT)*. Force being a word for a waterfall.

daily-cryptic.solution: DELEGACY – LEGACY(what you might get from a will) after DE(“from” in French)
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29080 – yep, it’s Tricky Thursday! – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Cooperate with others in summons to table (3,5)
daily-cryptic.solution:
GET ALONG – ET AL (with others) in GONG (summons to table)

Thanks to vinyl for this parsing! I should start calling my kids to dinner with a gong…
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic No 28913 — Am I being trolled? – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Be inconsistent, with indignant cry interrupting informal greeting (2-2)
daily-cryptic.solution: YO-YO – Y(OY)O.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28819 –  The best-laid schemes…. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: WHITE NIGHT –  sounds like “white knight”, a chap who rescues a company in financial trouble; a white night happens in high latitudes in summer when the daylight last all night and people hold festivals and don’t bother sleeping.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28893 – cracking the egg – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Reportedly nothing large eaten by one American sea creature (8)
daily-cryptic.solution: NAUTILUS – homophone of (reportedly) NOUGHT (nothing) + L (large) in (eated by) I (one) US (American)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic No 28877 — Things to chew on – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Nosy, first to look a veteran nursing home over (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: NASAL – The first letter of L[ook] plus A plus SAN[antorium] for an antique nursing home, all reversed (over)
daily-cryptic.title: 29014 Nothing to get stuck on – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: SEVERAL – S(EVER)AL[on].   It took me a while to see why going equals on, but think of a machine in operation.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29035 – Department of tricky literals – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: ENGLISHMAN –  Anagram of NIAMH’S GLEN.    For bonus points, pronounce Niamh correctly.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29023 – Take it easy, either way… – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Brief exercise involving Navy vessels (4)
daily-cryptic.solution: URNS – USe (exercise) minus the last (brief), containing RN (Royal Navy).

daily-cryptic.solution: PAGEANTRY – AGE (time) inside PANTRY a food store.

daily-cryptic.solution: CHIMERA – C (about) + anagram of HAIR around ME

daily-cryptic.clue: Milan side  put in grave position? (5)

daily-cryptic.solution:
INTER
Double definition
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28928 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: POMPOUS – Took me a while to remember George POMPIDOU. Keep the ’S, remove the ID papers.
daily-cryptic.title: 29002 Well, I felt lucky… – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Observe rising anger in thoroughfare (6)

daily-cryptic.solution: PLUCKY – P + LUCKY, a chestnut.

daily-cryptic.solution: PREVENT – PREsENT becomes PREVENT
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28897 – Lib Lab – Times for The Times

ASTI
ST (way) contained by [to tuck into] A1 (excellent)

daily-cryptic.solution: DISTAL – ST(stone) inside DIAL(ring)

daily-cryptic.solution: STROVE – ST(R)OVE.

daily-cryptic.solution: MARDI GRAS – Anagram of DIAGRAMS + R[ector].

daily-cryptic.solution: SOHO – OS (huge) reversed + HO (house)

daily-cryptic.solution: PEDESTAL -PEST an nuisance, insert ED[itor], add A, L.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28893 – cracking the egg – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: OFFICER – a retired skater would be OFF (the) ICE, add R for run.

daily-cryptic.clue: Nick right to be upset with old addict (7)
daily-cryptic.solution: TROUSER — RT (right) reversed (to be upset) + O (old) + USER (addict)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28957 – some might say you lack a blogger – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Go over need for measure of conductivity (6,3)
daily-cryptic.solution:
ENERGY GAP
ENERGY (go), GAP (need – e.g. a gap in the market). Collins: energy gap – in physics, the difference of energy between the bottom of the conduction band and the top of the valence band of the electrons in a crystalline solid. So now I know  – not!
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 29048 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: MANUFACTURE – MANURE = nasty material (except for gardeners), insert U for universal and FACT for truth.

daily-cryptic.solution: NAILED – Careful separating needed. Home is IN, which is reversed with A installed. The LED for light follows
daily-cryptic.title: 29002 Well, I felt lucky… – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Huge area included in visits regularly (4)
daily-cryptic.solution: VAST – V[i](A)S[i]T[s].

daily-cryptic.solution: LIMB – LB (libra, pounds), insert I M.

daily-cryptic.solution: EMMENTHAL – [th]EM + ME(N)T HAL.   I would have biffed this if I were confident of my spelling abilities.

daily-cryptic.clue: Rig renovation I arranged giving new strength (14)
daily-cryptic.solution: REINVIGORATION – RIG RENOVATION I anagrammed (arranged)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic No 28829 — Glutton for punishment – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Religious leader shortly after midnight taking in mass (4)
daily-cryptic.solution:
IMAM
1AM (shortly after midnight) containing [taking in] M (mass)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28940 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution:
WHAT FOR
Two meanings. Collins explains the first: informal – a punishment or reprimand, especially in the phrase ‘give (a person) what for’.
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28814 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Wild fire appearing shortly after wounding remark (9)
daily-cryptic.solution: BARBAROUS – AROUSE(fire) minus the final letter following BARB(wounding remark)
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29056 – Tricky Thursday is finding the thing! – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Taunt Stoic regularly? Everyone must join in (5)

TUTTI
T{a}U{n}T {s}T{o}I{c} [regularly]. Seen in music scores sometimes when the whole orchestra is about to play at the same time.

daily-cryptic.clue: One into wine, note, that’s average (8)
daily-cryptic.solution: MEDIOCRE – I (one) in MEDOC (wine) + RE (note after ‘do’ and before ‘mi’).

daily-cryptic.solution: ENTIRE – the NT is inserted into EIRE which is mistakenly believed to be the official Irish name for the Republic of Ireland. (It’s actually the Irish for the whole 32-county island, but the stamps do say “Eire”.) It’s properly called, Poblacht na hÉireann, which won’t fit on a stamp.

daily-cryptic.solution: SWEAR WORD – SWEAR and WORD two types of promise.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28905 – no need for m’aidez on May Day. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution:
ADENOIDAL – LA-DI-DA (pretentious) around ONE reversed (turning up)

It was around the time I solved this clue that my mind blew up.
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic No 28913 — Am I being trolled? – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Royal imprisoning current extremists in powerful rule (9)
daily-cryptic.solution: PRINCIPLE – PRINCE(royal) containing I(current) and the external letters in PowerfuL

daily-cryptic.clue: Second option mostly involving ultimate academic (10)
daily-cryptic.solution: SCHOLASTIC -LAST in S CHOICe
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28909 – Mon dieu! – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution:
MEET – reversal of TEEM (brim)

Brim as a verb.
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic No 29057 — Wag the dog – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: District hospital defended by old man (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: SHIRE – SIRE (old man) with H inside.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 28905 – no need for m’aidez on May Day. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Larva, one a lizard periodically rejected (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: NAIAD – every other letter from oNe A lIzArD.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29063 – a graceful dance – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Gypsy man features in Post Office advertisement (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: PROMO – Gypsy man is ROM, contained in P[ost] O[ffice].
daily-cryptic.title: 28942  Our survey says: completed at a cantur – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Alarm about family’s use of certain cosmetics? (8)

SKINCARE
SCARE (alarm) containing [about] KIN (family)
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28940 – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution:
COARSE
Sounds like [on the radio] “course” (programme)

THIRSTED – half of CAST + E (note) in (during) THIRD (interval)

Here THIRD is a musical interval.
daily-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic 28889 — My American is showing – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.solution: SPENT – SENT (given errand) has P for pennies inside.

daily-cryptic.clue: Upset stomach, with bad days drinking cola (9)
daily-cryptic.solution:
DYSPEPSIA
Anagram [bad] of DAYS containing [drinking] PEPSI (cola). Does somebody at The Times have shares in this product?

daily-cryptic.clue: Healthier, having swallowed right bit of food (7)
daily-cryptic.solution: FRITTER – F(R)ITTER.
daily-cryptic.title: Times 29071 – Just as the Tide was a-Flowing – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Twangy start to accompaniment disturbing northern girl (5)
daily-cryptic.solution: NASAL – The first of Accompaniment within N(orthern) and the random girl Sal
daily-cryptic.title: 28834 Probably would puzzle a monkey. – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Young man, a king or Russian noble (5)
daily-cryptic.solution:
BOYAR
BOY (young man), A, R (king). NHO this despite having ancestors from that part of the world. Its only two previous appearances here were  in Mephistos.

daily-cryptic.clue: Mastermind in part of family touring India (6)
daily-cryptic.solution:
GENIUS
GENUS (part of family) containing [touring] I (India – NATO)

daily-cryptic.clue: Agreeable notes written about clubs inside paved area (9)
daily-cryptic.solution: SIMPATICO – The note to pluralise and then reverse (written about) is MI, then add C[lubs] inside PATIO, a paved area. Chambers says it’s “Sympathetic in the sense of congenial” and derives as you might expect from Italian and Spanish
daily-cryptic.title: 28978 A lying POTUS. Imagine that! – Times for The Times

daily-cryptic.clue: Short TV feature about northern tip (5)

quick-cryptic.clue: Confusion of woody grass unknown element topped (13)
quick-cryptic.solution:
BAMBOOZLEMENT – BAMBOO (‘woody grass’) Z (‘unknown’) ELEMENT (‘element topped’=first letter deleted)

Very appropriate as I was, well, bamboozled by this one, being unable to shift “bemusement” when I had the crossing B and M.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2621 by Breadman: Bewitched, bewothered and bewildered – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Napoleonic battle seen in mundane journal picked up (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: JENA – reverse hidden word. Battle of Jena, 14th October 1806. Not one I was familiar with. The sum total of my Napoleonic Wars knowledge is that he lost.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2648 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Puff,  brilliant idea (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: WHEEZE -A DD, with the second usually seen in the phrase “cunning wheeze” – indeed, can a wheeze ever be anything other than cunning?
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2751 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Son concealing longing to be a theatre performer? (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: SURGEON – SON contains URGE (longing)
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2627 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Fairly regularly holding the helm for gunners (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: ARTILLERY – Alternate letters of fAiRlY with TILLER (helm) inserted
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2576 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Buttering up cook carrying coffee (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: FLATTERY — FRY (cook) holding (carrying) LATTE (coffee)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2746 by Joker – no animals were harmed in setting this crossword – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Dried fruit that’s popular, they say (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
CURRANT – sounds like [they say] CURRENT (popular)

Current=popular seems a bit of a stretch. Popular music (as in pop) originally just meant CURRENT.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2813 by Pipsqueak – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Heart in trouble after lung treated — not appreciative (10)
quick-cryptic.solution:
UNGRATEFUL – {tro}U{ble} [Heart in] + (AFTER LUNG)* [treated]

An easy solve but a tough parse. “Heart in” meaning “middle letter of”, and “after” not being a positional indicator, but part of the anagram.

I had to use some aids on this one, thanks Ross at Crossword Genius.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2591 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Wholly engrossed, knocked sharply to be heard (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: RAPT – Sounds like [to be heard] “rapped” (knocked sharply).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2778 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Shrubs that could be provided by dealer and son (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: OLEANDERS – (dealer son)*, the anagram indicator being “provided by”.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2763 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Search round for dance band (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: COMBO – COMB (search) + O (round).  “Combo”, short for combination, was originally 1920s US slang for a jazz band, but has become more widely applied and is used now for dance bands and other musical groups as well.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2781 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Swindle German wife and daughter (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: FRAUD – FRAU (German wife) D (daughter).

quick-cryptic.solution: BOAR – sounds like BORE

quick-cryptic.solution: TERRAPIN — We are inserting (burying) the first of Presents in TERRAIN (earth)

quick-cryptic.clue: Attitude adopted by oldest ancestors (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: STANCE – “adopted” by oldeST ANCEstors
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2689 by Kenny – Times for The Times

BAWL
Aural wordplay [sounds like]: “ball” (bouncer)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2704 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.solution: QUEBEC – Hidden (‘partly apparent’) in ‘mosQUE BEComes’
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2747 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: The girl left short term refuge (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: SHELTER – SHE (the girl) + L (left) + TER (“short” term)
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2685 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Trot out standard rubbish (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: PARROT – PAR (standard), ROT (rubbish).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2754 by Lupa – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Took Jack for pilgrimage (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: HADJ – the HADJ (more usually spelt HAJJ) is a pilgrimage to Mecca which all Muslims are supposed to make at least once in their lives, wealth and health permitting. HAD for “took” + J for “Jack” (as in (Ox)bridge).  I knew this alternative spelling because back in the day my sister-in-law used to fly jets full of pilgrims from Indonesia to Mecca. She found it both amusing and infuriating that it was fine for a woman to operate a Boeing 737 but she then couldn’t hire a car.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2611 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Radical doctor having wine with bit of cocaine (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: DRASTIC — DR (doctor) with ASTI and the first letter or bit of Cocaine
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2830 by Alex – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Role model is generous, putting former partner first (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: EXAMPLE – AMPLE (generous) with EX first
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2780 by Asp – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: What could make alarm break out — ignoring a factor of job economics (6,6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
LABOUR MARKET – (alarm break out)*, with the removal of one of the A’s indicated by “ignoring a” and the anagram indicator being “what could make”.

A very slightly convoluted piece of word order in the wordplay I think, as the natural reading would suggest that what one is trying to make is the phrase “alarm break out”, and one has in effect to add an A not ignore it to get there from the letters of Labour Market.  But the meaning of the clue is clear enough.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2835 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Sandy’s liveliness (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
GINGER – Double definition

As mentioned in the introduction, I had trouble with this which was my LOI by some margin. I think of GINGER as more of a reddish colour, and GINGER for ‘liveliness’ didn’t occur to me. Both senses are in the usual places with GINGER as “yellowish-brown” in Collins.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2693 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Fellow making section of book much shorter (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: CHAP – CHAP{ter} (section of a book) much shorter.

quick-cryptic.clue: Broadcaster in South American city screening commercial (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: RADIO – RIO (South American city) with AD (commercial) inside it [screening].
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2706 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Raise army to cross India (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
HOIST – HOST (army) contains I{ndia}

Host for army is common in crosswords, even though it hasn’t been used in a military sense since ancient times.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2651 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Foam moving forth (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
FROTH – Anagram [moving] of FORTH.

I’m bad at anagrams, but this was literally just switching two letters.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2562 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Some era — generally a long period (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
AGE
Hidden in [some] {er}A GE{nerally}
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2644 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Unusually nice lad in charge of N Atlantic island (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: ICELANDIC – anagram (“unusually”) of “nice lad” + IC for “in charge”.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2839 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Legally qualified European held in contempt unfortunately (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: COMPETENT – E for “European” inside an anagram (“unfortunately”) of “contempt”. Chambers has “legally capable” as sense 3. A bit marginal but I suppose it works: competent to drive/legally qualified to drive, though I have known people who were one but not the other.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2659 by Joker – the evil gin does would be hard to assess. – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Strange daydream about ecstasy being immediately available (5-4)
quick-cryptic.solution: READY-MADE – (DAYDREAM)* “about” E (ecstasy)
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2757 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Express disapproval of bishop? That would be a mistake (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: BOOB – BOO (express disapproval) + B for bishop [chess].
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2838 by Pipsqueak – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Runner is upset going round centre of Tokyo (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: SKI – SI [IS reversed] contains K [middle letter of toKyo]
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2627 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: A gesture of respect that’s far from stern (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
BOW – Double def, BOW is the front (“pointy end”) of a ship, far from the stern (“square end”)

Its a heteronym, the words are spelled identically but have different sounds
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2837 by Peridot – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Put down leader, get excited (9)
quick-cryptic.solution:
RELEGATED – (leader get)*, with the anagram indicator being “excited”.

Down as in “sent to a lower position or league”, and I think I would more naturally say “go down”, which my football team seems perennially to be in danger of doing, rather than “put down”, which has more the sense of terminating something’s life (and maybe what the team deserves for all the pain it gives its supporters!).  But the meaning is clear and the synonym is probably close enough.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2799 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Huge stone finally going in the mail, remarkably (8)
quick-cryptic.solution:
MEGALITH – (THE MAIL)* [remarkably] contains {goin}G

I first read this as {Ston}E (finally) going in (THE MAIL)* and that’s the anagram I worked on.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2765 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Unusually, direct something seen at end of film (6)
quick-cryptic.definition: something seen at end of film
quick-cryptic.solution: CREDIT – anagram (“unusually”) of “direct”.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2647 by Myles – what did the MCC ever do for us? – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Birmingham maybe securing a victory, initially hollow (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: CAVITY — CITY (Birmingham maybe) around (securing) A and Victory initially
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2650 by Pedro – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: A poet, I fancy narcotic (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: OPIATE – (A POET I)* [fancy]
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2819 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Pine cut short for a period of time (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: YEAR – “yearn” (“pine”) without its last letter (“cut short”).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2563 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Abandon plane? No, lie back! (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: JETTISON – JET (plane) NO, SIT (no, lie) “back”.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2665 by Corelli – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Knocked around Northern Ireland and drove off (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: BANISHED — BASHED (knocked) around NI (Northern Ireland)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2638 by Alex – pigs mean prizes – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Romans insist on changing conveyance (12)
quick-cryptic.solution: TRANSMISSION — Once anagrammed (… on changing) ROMANS INSIST
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2830 by Alex – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Oscar, writing half-heartedly, finds opportunity (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
OPENING – O (Oscar in the NATO phonetic alphabet) + PENnING (writing, half-heartedly).

I’m going to be a bit pedantic here and say that “half-heartedly” should mean to find the middle letters and remove half of them. Which means you can only do that to words with even numbers of letters: the two Ns in PENNING are not in the middle: only the second N is in the middle. Not my favorite clue, but one that I was happy to bung in and move on while solving, less happy with when writing the explanation.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2682 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Leave work permanently and go to bed (6)
quick-cryptic.definition: leave work permanently / go to bed
quick-cryptic.solution:
RETIRE
Two meanings

quick-cryptic.clue: Judge a female beast of burden? (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ASSESS
ASS-ESS (female beast of burden)

quick-cryptic.clue: One’s stuck in quagmire, the story of my life (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: BIOG – I inside BOG.

quick-cryptic.clue: One in road moved fast (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: RACED – RD (road) contains ACE (one)
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2567 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Regret the way of Napoleon (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: RUE – ‘way’ or ‘street’ to the French-speaking Napoleon would be RUE
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2664 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Zany crew gatecrashing start of school dance (9)
quick-cryptic.solution:
SCREWBALL – CREW inserted into [gatecrashing] S{chool} [start of i.e. first letter of] then BALL (dance)

SCREWBALL comedy, which gets its name from a type of breaking pitch in baseball where the ball goes in the opposite direction to other types of breaking pitch, was a popular film subgenre of the romantic comedy genre, putting the emphasis on the spoofing of love.

Typical elements included fast-paced overlapping repartee, farcical situations, escapist themes, the battle of the sexes, disguise and masquerade amidst plot lines often involving courtship and marriage (or re-marriage).

The first film credited as a screwball was Three-Cornered Moon (1933) starring Claudette Colbert.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2676 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: One wrapped up in Bottom’s performance (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
RECITAL
I (one) contained [wrapped up] in RECTAL (bottom’s)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2728 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Place to gamble on savings account, Charlie having retired (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
CASINO – ON + ISA (savings account) + C [Charlie {NATO alphabet)] all reversed (retired)

A reminder of my old croupier days.  Gamble responsibly folks.

An ISA (Individual Savings Account) is very much a UK term but is also a bit of a crossword standard, so not unfamiliar.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2673 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Badger blokes caught by civil wrong (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
TORMENT – MEN (blokes) inserted into (ie “caught by”) TORT (civil wrong).

Torment was an answer as recently as last Wednesday (QC 2700), when Pedro clued it as “Left-winger taken aback about blokes in distress”.  Do we detect some angst in the setters’ coffee-room?
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2703 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Flowering plant is decennial unusually (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: CELANDINE – Anagram [unusually] of DECENNIAL.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2670 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: First model, a rarity originally, very high price (3,6)
quick-cryptic.solution: TOP DOLLAR – TOP (first) DOLL (model) A R (Rarity “originally”)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2845 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: “Farewell” here translated, one parting company (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: CHEERIO – A complex construction, with HEER (anagram of here, the anagram indicator being “translated”) + I (one) all inserted into (“parting”) CO (company).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2751 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Ghost wandering around Hampton (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: PHANTOM – anagram (“wandering around”) of “Hampton”. Lovely surface.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2767 by Felix – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Turmoil minutes after master interrupted by learner (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: MAELSTROM – the final M is for “minutes” (nautical positioning), which comes “after” MAESTRO (“master”) with an L inside (“interrupted by learner”).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2647 by Myles – what did the MCC ever do for us? – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Political event with left replacing right in House, perhaps (8)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ELECTION – ERECTION (house, perhaps) with L (left) replacing R (right)

There’ll be one later this year in America, not that you hear much about it.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2757 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Double praise returned (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: DUAL – “laud” backwards (“returned”). Very neat.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2611 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Initially Omani spy aims to disturb meetings (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: SYMPOSIA – (O {mani} SPY AIMS)* [to disturb]
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2699 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: French city hosting English relation (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: NIECE – NICE with E inside

quick-cryptic.clue: Nation that’s initially angry over hill and dale? (5-7)
quick-cryptic.solution: CROSS-COUNTRY — COUNTRY (nation) preceded by (that’s initially) CROSS (angry)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2782 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Valley seeing return of English youth (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: DALE – E (English) + LAD (youth), all reversed (“return of”).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2775 by Felix – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Go before or quietly go back? (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: PRECEDE – P (quietly) + RECEDE (go back)
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2813 by Pipsqueak – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Cheaper drugs distributed: more potent (12)
quick-cryptic.solution:
SUPERCHARGED
Anagram [distributed] of CHEAPER DRUGS
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2812 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Washing that’s delicate in sack (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: BATHING – THIN inside BAG
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2636 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Going to be published before spring (8)
quick-cryptic.solution:
OUTBOUND – OUT (‘to be published’) coming in front of (‘before’) BOUND (‘spring’)

A couple of separations in the surface reading, between ‘Going’ and ‘to be published’ and between ‘before’ and ‘spring’, required here.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2561 by Myles – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Having the right to a loosening of Lent diet? (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: ENTITLED – anagram (“loosening”) of “Lent diet”.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2827 by Bjorn – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Great sites for redevelopment according to schemes (10)
quick-cryptic.solution:
STRATEGIES – Anagram (‘for redevelopment’) of GREAT SITES

I don’t think ‘according to’ is part of the def but on the other hand I’m not sure what it is doing in the clue, as it’s not even necessary for the surface if ‘schemes’ by itself is the def.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2753 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Mark confined to bed, otherwise (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: DOT – “confined” to beD OTherwise – well hidden!
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2845 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: A brief hearing in the courts once (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ATRIA – A (‘A’) TRIAL (‘brief hearing’=last letter of TRIAL deleted)

The word (singular atrium) is still used today of course for a (usually large) entrance hall, but the ‘courts once’ refers to “An open-roofed entrance hall or central court in an ancient Roman house” (ODE). The chamber of the heart use of the word has also come from this sense.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2609 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Take side off piece of furniture to make it fit (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: ABLE – {t}ABLE (piece of furniture), without the letter on the left-hand side of the word, [take side off]. I don’t think I’ve seen “take side off” as a deletion indicator before.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2678 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Very old priest involved with choir (11)
quick-cryptic.solution: PREHISTORIC – anagram (“involved”) of PRIEST + CHOIR.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2803 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Evaluate end of song in NT book (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
JUDGE – SONG [end of i.e. last letter of] in JUDE (NT book)

JUDE is the penultimate book of the New Testament and my penultimate answer in the grid – should probably memorise a list of the books…
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2628 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Infrequent cop raids disrupted (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: SPORADIC – Anagram [disrupted] of COP RAIDS
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2784 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Excited, I start to gambol between rugby posts (4)
quick-cryptic.solution:
HIGH – I + G (start to gambol) between two H’s (rugby posts)

Rugby posts are H-shaped.  You need to get the ball over the crossbar and between the uprights to count as a goal.  (If anyone mentions Johnny Wilkinson in 2003 they will be banned from this website).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2661 by Pedro – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Mum in highest part of ship (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
MAINTOP – MA (Mum), IN, TOP (highest).

Lift and separate “highest part of ship”.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2694 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Trendies, alas, ruined Pacific location (6,6)
quick-cryptic.solution: EASTER ISLAND – (Trendies alas)* [ruined].
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2666 by Pedro – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Catch husband maybe nearly keeling over (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ENTRAP
PARTNE{r} (husband maybe) [nearly], reversed [keeling over]
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2596 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: In gospel truth this reptile goes backwards (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: TURTLE — In gospEL TRUTh the answer is found backwards (this … goes backwards)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2578 by Joker – swings and roundabouts – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Perennial protesters seemingly being rude to barmen (4-1-3)
quick-cryptic.solution: RENT-A-MOB – (to barmen)* [seemingly being rude]. Is there no end to the different ways to indicate an anagram? Apparently not! Well not one I’ve seen before, anyway. There was a lot of discussion abut this. Thanks to Penfold for clearing it up. “Chambers has rent-a defined as Denoting: (as if) rented or hired, organized for a specific occasion or purpose. So I think that must make “Perennial protesters seemingly” the definition as a “rent-a-mob” isn’t always the same people, it’s just as expression that suggests it is.”  So it’s (to barmen)* [rude].
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2594 by Felix – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: One in penny casino game losing pound in turn (9)
quick-cryptic.solution:
PIROUETTE
I (one) contained by [in] P (penny) + ROU{l}ETTE (casino game) [losing pound]. Spinning round in ballet.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2728 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Prohibits importing European seeds (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
BEANS
BANS (prohibits) containing [importing] E (European)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2560 by Alex – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Irate Mod disturbed negotiator (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: MEDIATOR – anagram (disturbed) of IRATE MOD
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2821 by Lupa – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: English make an impression with beheading sovereign (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
EMPRESS – E (English), IMPRESS (make an impression) without its first letter [with beheading].

This could have been made much harder by using a phrase other than “make an impression”. But I’ll take the crumbs of comfort.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2670 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Vehicle in Central African Republic, originally (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
CAR – initial letters of Central African Republic

Doesn’t get much easier than this.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2591 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: One checking car on hill (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
AUDITOR – AUDI (‘car’) above in a down clue (‘on’) TOR (‘hill’)

AUDI for ‘car’ comes up frequently in crosswords, I think even more so than another four-letter alternative, MINI.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2723 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Illogical to pay a poet thus? (8)
quick-cryptic.solution:
PERVERSE – It’s illogical to pay a poet PER VERSE

Clever, not sure how to classify the clue, as the definition is doing double duty, as part of the cryptic definition as well.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2735 by Pipsqueak – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Flower was a climber? (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: ROSE – cryptic hint, referring to rising/climbing
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2581 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Religious text starts to question unusual rationales about Neo-Christianity (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: QURAN – the first letters (“starts to”) of “question unusual rationales about Neo-Christianity”. I’m glad that the spelling was in the clue because I’d naturally have used “Koran”. I hadn’t come across the phrase “Neo-Christianity” before; per Collins, it means “any interpretation of Christianity based on the prevalent philosophy of a given period”.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2695 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Lifted, first prize (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
POT – TOP (first) reversed [lifted]

Pot = slang for a cup (trophy), common in crosswords rare in IRL.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2777 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Black ducks show disapproval (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: BOO – B (Black) OO (ducks – a duck is a zero score for a batsman’s/batswoman’s innings in cricket)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2772 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Old friend finding precious stone (4)
quick-cryptic.solution:
OPAL
O (old), PAL (friend)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2596 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Piece of cake and cheeses for the audience (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
BREEZE
Sounds like [for the audience] “Bries” (cheeses]
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2656 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Fastening made from odd bits of twine (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: TIE – T{w}I{n}E
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2603 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Fog is surrounding mount? On the contrary (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: MIST – Lateral thinking required here:  IS surrounding MT (for mount) would give IMTS, which is not a word.  But “the contrary” is MT surrounding IS, which is a word and gives us our answer MIST.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2691 by Pedro – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Grand, in the manner of festival (4)
quick-cryptic.solution:
GALA – G for Grand, A LA (in the manner of).

I tried and discarded both MALA and KALA. Thought I’d have to brush up on my Festivals Of All Religions knowledge, until the idea of just using G for grand dawned on me.

Put yourself in the novels of Raymond Chandler with people who spit out of the side of their mouths: “He owed me a hundred Gs, he had it comin’.” You’re welcome.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2598 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Fellow performer requiring money to be paid and all royalties up front (2-4)
quick-cryptic.solution: CO-STAR – COST (money to be paid) and A R (All Royalties “up front”)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2641 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Unseemly outburst is noticed on a podcast (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
SCENE – Sounds like SEEN (is noticed)

“On a podcast” is a new way of indicating a homophone. “One the Radio” is the more common indicator, but many people listen to podcasts instead of the radio, so this is a good update.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2759 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Resolute golfer’s support for furniture item (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: SETTEE – SET (Resolute) + TEE (golfer’s support).  A classic “lift and separate” – we are not considering a determined golfer here.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2583 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Distinguished? Not the person who oversees these puzzles (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: NOTED – NOT ED (editor; the person who oversees these puzzles).
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2774 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Most pure Charles facing ordeal? (8)
quick-cryptic.solution:
CHASTEST – CHAS [abbreviation for Charles] + TEST (ordeal).

In my youth, I knew a Charles who went by Chas. I’ve never met another since.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2658 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Part of a flight coming from best airport (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
STAIR – A hidden, in beST AIRport, with the indicator being “coming from”.

Oh that type of flight, and nothing to do with birds, aeroplanes or people fleeing.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2739 by Jimmy – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: High-class fruit eaten by an android (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: AUTOMATON – U (High Class) + TOMATO (fruit) inside AN
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2729 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Flora’s partner heads for football arena up north, actually (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: FAUNA -First letters [heads] of Football Arena Up North Actually. Often paired in the phrase FLORA and FAUNA, which refers to the plants and animals of a particular region.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2762 by Jimmy – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Almond fanatic? (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: NUT – Why the question mark if NUT is synonymous with “fanatic”? Perhaps it isn’t quite? Discuss.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2592 by Lupa – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Snake of a short species (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: ASP – A and SP. (an abbrev. for species)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2785 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Backing inexperienced leader, an explosive sort (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: WARHEAD – Reversal (‘Backing’) of RAW (‘inexperienced’) = WAR then HEAD (‘leader’)
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2645 by Bubbles – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Good to have academic dress (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: GOWN – G for “good” + OWN for “to have”.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2611 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Support for limb motionless initially in seizure (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: ARMREST – Motionless [initially] in ARREST (seizure).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2646 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Sombre Aussie soldier, one working in churchyard (11)
quick-cryptic.solution: GRAVEDIGGER -GRAVE for “sombre” + DIGGER for “Aussie soldier”. Collins has it as Australians more generally than soldiers – hence Rupert Murdoch’s Private Eye nickname, The Dirty Digger.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2803 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Huge nation lacking a feature (4)
quick-cryptic.solution:
CHIN
CHIN{a} (huge nation) [lacking ‘a’]
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2836 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Bill — and what he hopes to be when singing? (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
INVOICE
IN VOICE (what he – Bill – hopes to be when singing)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2788 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Bats evidently live flying round … yes, initially here? (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: BELFRY – the first letters (“initially”) of Bats Evidently Live Flying Round Yes.  But what to underline as the definition?  It could be the whole clue, or perhaps just the words Bats … live … here.  That would break all the rules though, so I have gone for just the word “here”, as where bats evidently live.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2715 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Lana is confused about time of birth (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: NATAL – (LANA)* “about” T (time)
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2817 by Corelli – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Container receipt missing one parcel we oddly overlooked (10)
quick-cryptic.solution: RECEPTACLE – RECEPT (= RECEIPT minus I) + alternate letters of pArCeL wE. Arrgh – spent three minutes staring at this trying to think of a synonym for ‘receipt’, which is how this clue would work in the 15×15. Here in Quickie land, they can use the actual word rather than the synonym.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2732 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Sovereign in French street, bearing left then right (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
RULER
RUE (French street) containing [bearing] L (left), then R (right)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2668 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Fitting grand, you see ultimately (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: DUE – the last letters (“ultimately”) of “granD, yoU seE“.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2623 by Hurley – hello Dr Purr – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Touch European pond creature (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: TADPOLE – TAD (touch, as in “little bit”) + POLE (European).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2598 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Repeat concerning request (10)
quick-cryptic.solution: REPETITION – RE (concerning) PETITION (request)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2821 by Lupa – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Obscure band that rivalled Oasis (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: BLUR – Double definition, the second being those purveyors of inexplicably popular Britpop garbage
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2768 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Allow older female relative time (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: GRANT – GRAN is your “older female relative” + T for “time”.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2827 by Bjorn – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Forest dwellers love visiting pubs (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
BOARS – O (‘love’) contained in (‘visiting’) BARS (‘pubs’)

Our porcine clue at last.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2723 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Home acquired metallic bar? (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: INGOT – IN (home) + GOT (acquired).

quick-cryptic.clue: Lumbermen accepting fine: DA to direct piercing glare (4,7)
quick-cryptic.solution: LOOK DAGGERS – lumbermen (LOGGERS) around fine (OK) and DA is, erm, DA.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2565 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Sudden cry of ox maniac let loose (11)
quick-cryptic.solution: EXCLAMATION – (OX MANIAC LET)*
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2579 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Tiny part from a male cat (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: ATOM – A TOM (male cat).
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2630 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Something to fill gaps when mammal and insect meet (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: SEALANT – SEAL (mammal) ANT (insect).
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2798 by Alex – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Two different pandas? One huge star! (3,5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
RED GIANT
RED + GIANT (two different pandas)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2584 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Japanese band seen in Bielsko-Biala (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
OBI
Hidden [seen] in {Bielsk}O-BI{ala}
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2584 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: British individual keeps a role for French ruler (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: BONAPARTE – B{ritish} + ONE (individual) contains A + PART (role)
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2615 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Tube where growths come up (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: STRAW – WARTS (growths) reversed, [come up] in a down clue.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2786 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Keep piano book (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: PRESERVE – P for “piano” + RESERVE for “book”, as in “I must reserve/book a table”. That threw me, because I was fixated on “book” as a noun. 3-2 Mara.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2815 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Something opponents may do to do the opposite (5)
quick-cryptic.definition: something opponents may do to do the opposite
quick-cryptic.solution: AGREE – Cryptic definition, based on the phrase “agree to disagree” (or as I had it “agree to differ”). A bit contrived, I feel, but maybe it’s just too clever for me.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2618 by Myles – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Very little or slightly drunk (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
TIDDLY
Two meanings
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2620 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Further article on London Symphony Orchestra (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: ALSO – A (article) on LSO
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2713 by Pipsqueak – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Course, unfashionable, in Religious Education (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: ROUTE – OUT (unfashionable) in RE (Religious Education)
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2787 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: European state slipping into sea (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ESTONIA
Anagram [slipping] of INTO SEA
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2668 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Go away, packing some current hair product (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
SHAMPOO — SHOO (go away) contains AMP (some current)

I think “some” here is a truncation indicator, for Ampere. Although not really needed as Amp is the widely used abbreviation.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2843 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Volume is difficult to support (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: HARDBACK – HARD (difficult) + BACK (support)
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2660 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Cunning old monarch, a Sagittarius (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ARCHER – ARCH (Cunning) ER (old monarch – Elizabeth Regina)

Sagittarius is a southern constellation and the ninth sign of the zodiac – the Latin name means “pertaining to arrows”.

The star-picture represents a centaur drawing a bow, which scholars suspect to have depicted originally, a Babylonian god, but which to modern observers, looks vaguely like a teapot.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2772 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: It goes badly for bighead (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: EGOIST – (it goes)* [badly].
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2618 by Myles – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Regularly tell off mischievous child? (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ELF – {t}e{l}l{o}f{f}

Mischievous is more often an Imp. At my primary school (Telford School, Leamington Spa) the classes were called Fairies, Imps, Nymphs, Elves, Pixies, Gnomes, Sprites and Brownies.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2567 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Reported bivalve’s strength (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: MUSCLE – sounds like (“reported”) MUSSEL (bivalve)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2785 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Football team’s magazine (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ARSENAL – Double definition.

Oh, that sort of magazine. Given that the team’s nickname is “The Gunners”, I’m slightly ashamed that this took as long as it did…
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2670 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Take steps to eliminate lead troublemaker online (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: TROLL – STROLL (take steps) eliminating the lead letter
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2769 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Extreme weather disturbed hot pony (7)
quick-cryptic.solution: TYPHOON – (HOT PONY)*
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2709 by Trelawney – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Dastardly con destroyed police headquarters (8,4)
quick-cryptic.solution: SCOTLAND YARD — DASTARDLY CON anagrammed (destroyed)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2638 by Alex – pigs mean prizes – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Creature leaving sinking ship? Sailor returned (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: RAT – TAR backwards
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2684 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Relative caught in fiasco US instigated (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: COUSIN – hidden (“caught in”) inside “fiasco US instigated”.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2779 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Doing one better than while taking ecstasy, it might make you swell up (3,5)
quick-cryptic.definition: it might make you swell up
quick-cryptic.solution: BEE STING – BESTING (doing one better than) while taking E(cstasy)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2725 by Beck – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Indication in letter read aloud? (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
CUE — Sounds like (… read aloud?) Q (letter)
Cue is also the spelling of the letter Q, so the clue would also work without the last two words.  It is of course perfectly fine and good this way too.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2722 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Match inevitably drawn? (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
TIE
Cryptic
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2812 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: English in British state work hard (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: BEAVER — E (English) in B (British) plus AVER (state)
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2794 by Wurm – did not fini – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Conscious of fighting in A&E (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
AWARE – WAR (fighting) in A + E

I so wanted this to be AWAKE, but could not find any reason for WAK to mean fighting. Western Australia Karate club maybe.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2651 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Standing sculptures Moore finally turned out (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: STATUS – STATUES [sculptures with E (moorE finally) evicted (turned out)]
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2745 by Orpheus – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Good sense to retain Republican’s legal document (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: WRIT – WIT (good sense) retaining R (Republican)
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2637 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Vehicle about to go over animal’s remains (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
CARCASS – CAR (vehicle) + C (about) + ASS (animal)

The parsing is tricky as the clue could have been “Animal’s remains”, since a carcass is never used to refer to a human.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2687 by Oink – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Mathematician‘s ISA account recently opened with large amount (5,6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ISAAC NEWTON
ISA, AC, NEW (ISA. account. recently opened), TON (large amount). Tautology alert as ISA stands for ‘Individual Savings Account’,  but for crossword purposes we can lift and separate.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2692 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Second grade in a trial, ideally (2,4)
quick-cryptic.solution:
AT BEST – B (Second Grade) inside A TEST (A Trial)

Since we are in A-Level season I should point out that a B is actually the third grade, after A and A*.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2759 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Mix-up is severe when king goes missing (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: HASH – HArSH (severe) when R (Rex = king) goes missing
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2785 by Joker – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Wave hard with horse-rider, heading off for sport (6,6)
quick-cryptic.solution: ROLLER HOCKEY – ROLLER (wave) + H (hard) + jOCKEY (horse-rider [heading off]).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2574 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: They may unintentionally reveal sinful despair somehow (8,5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
FREUDIAN SLIPS – (SINFUL DESPAIR)*

Cracking anagram.

When singing Beethoven’s Ode to Joy in a choir many years ago, the basses came in a bar too early with a very loud “Freude” (Joy). The conductor said it was a Freudian Slip.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2789 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Where displaced Romanians may go? (3,6)
quick-cryptic.solution: SAN MARINO – (ROMANIANS)* [displaced]
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2807 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Some dealer, thorough, shows warning (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: ALERT – Hidden (‘Some’) in ‘deALER Thorough’
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2693 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Take over popular and successful recording involving Queen? (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
INHERIT – In (popular) + HIT (successful recording) contains ER (Queen)

I think Queen Elizabeth would now just be queen, with lower case. The Queen (upper case) must surely be Camilla now.
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2783 by Pedro – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Finally retired, Bill has houses in the country (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: DACHAS – D (“Finally” retireD) AC (account = bill) HAS. Rural houses in Russia.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2581 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Popular period at home with expert is boring (12)
quick-cryptic.solution: INTERMINABLE – IN (popular) + TERM (period) + IN (at home) + ABLE (expert, adjective)
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2780 by Asp – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Region in South Africa — or region of ancient Greece (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: SPARTA – PART (Region) inserted into SA (South Africa)

quick-cryptic.clue: Brit so confused in French restaurant (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
BISTRO – Anagram [confused] of BRIT SO

A BISTRO or bistrot, in its original Parisian form, is a small restaurant serving moderately priced, simple meals in a modest setting. The term has also become used by more pretentious restaurants.

Is it just the British that can take something modest and make it out to appear far more impressive than it is?

CANTANKEROUS – (A CURS TAKEN ON)* [manoeuvres as anagrind]

With “on manoeuvres” this gives a nice surface. Tory ministers are said to be “on manoeuvres” when they are jostling to defenestrate the leader, basically all of them, all the time, at the moment.

quick-cryptic.title: QC 2567 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: A rest for Ronnie O’Sullivan? (6)
quick-cryptic.solution: SPIDER – if you listen carefully you may hear the faint echo of howls of outrage in Australia, the US and elsewhere. Ronnie “the Rocket” O’Sullivan is a living person and in my book he definitely passes the “famous enough to be included?” test, because he’s one of the greatest snooker players of all time. But then I am aware of snooker, and I have to accept that it’s a sport with a more limited global (or even national) reach than, say, football. So not everyone will know him. But the real issue here is having to know not only (a) who he is and what he plays, but also (b) that snooker players sometimes use a thing called a “rest” to balance their cue on (if the cue ball is in an awkward spot which they can’t comfortably reach with their cue hand) and (c) that one particular (rather rarely used) type of such “rest” is called … a SPIDER.  Sense 9 in Collins: “billiards, snooker: a rest having long legs, used to raise the cue above the height of the ball”. I play pool and snooker and in fact I actually own a SPIDER but even so it took me a wee while to crack it because there’s no wordplay to guide you. Good luck if you had to trawl this – there are apparently 72 words that fit S-I-E-.

quick-cryptic.clue: Company learner getting pass (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: COL – CO (company) + L (learner), with the definition pass as in mountain pass.  My FOI.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2763 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Old druid drained rum (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ODD – O (Old) then the internal letters of D{rui}D are removed [drained]

In the 1560s, rum was canting slang [thieves’ jargon] meaning “excellent, fine, good, valuable”. By 1774, it had also come to mean rather the opposite: “odd, strange, bad, queer, spurious,” perhaps because it had been so often used approvingly by rogues, in reference to one another.

In recent years, wicked has taken the opposite journey, meaning both bad and good…
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2820 by Jimmy – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Finish session in a tie, losing heart (9)
quick-cryptic.solution: TERMINATE – TERM (session) + IN A (from the clue) + TE (tie “losing heart”, ie with the I, the middle letter or heart, deleted).

quick-cryptic.clue: Not all regular guests bicker (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: ARGUE – A hidden (ie “not all” of) in regulAR GUEsts.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2679 by Felix – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Saint who’s after some eggs? (8)
quick-cryptic.solution: BENEDICT – I really liked this and it gets my COD. “Eggs Benedict” is the name for ham and poached egg on top of a muffin, covered in Hollandaise sauce (yum). So BENEDICT is a saint whose name comes “after” “some” eggs (not all eggs, because there are lots of other ways to serve eggs). Very neat.

quick-cryptic.clue: Source of light in the middle of equinox month (3)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ARC – the middle letters of MARCh, a month that contains an equinox.

A two-step solve, first getting the month and then taking the middle letters. We don’t often see clues like this in the Quickie, but the crossers were very friendly.

quick-cryptic.solution:
ENNUI – EN (French for ‘in’: ‘in French’) + I for island around [engulfing] NU (Greek letter / character).

I biffed this one and then immediately thought, “but wait, French for ‘island’ is ‘ILE'”. So I didn’t trust that this was right until I’d got all the crossers and then I re-parsed, attaching ‘French’ to ‘in’ instead of to ‘island’.

quick-cryptic.clue: What may be thrown in Devon river (4)
quick-cryptic.definition: what may be thrown / devon rive

The River Dart is a river in Devon that rises high on Dartmoor and flows for about 50 miles to the sea at Dartmouth.  Along the way the river’s two main tributary branches, viz the East Dart and the West Dart, meet at, er, Dartmeet.  Devonians clearly like simple logical descriptive names for geographical features.

quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic 2571 by Juno – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Couple at the dinner table  spotted in black and white? (4,3,6)
quick-cryptic.definition: couple at the dinner table / spotted in black and white
quick-cryptic.solution:
SALT AND PEPPER – I was uncertain how to describe this clue, and in the end I think it is best seen as a pair of cryptic definitions.  The first wordplay element refers to salt and pepper pots, often a matching pair, and the second refers to “salt and pepper hair”, a term used for a mixture of dark and grey or white hairs and often an uncomfortable time as one tries with increasing lack of success to pretend one is not going grey!

However one chooses to describe the clue, it made me smile and was my COD.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2751 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.solution: UNCLEAR — UNCLE (family member) + A + R (right)

quick-cryptic.clue: Completely dark, unlike red carpet at Oscars ceremony? (8)

STARLESS
A cryptic hint accompanies the main definition

My LOI – this took me far too long, even with all of the checkers in place, and the assumption that the second word was SEAT. Tchoh!

quick-cryptic.solution: MOTION – double definition

quick-cryptic.solution:
BRIDGE – BRIDE (newly-wed) with G (golf in the NATO alphabet).

Bridge is a ‘tricky’ game in that it is a trick-based game. Very Uxbridge English Dictionary.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2778 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: European design producing strong feeling (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
EMOTIVE – E (European) MOTIVE (design)

I initially bunged in EMOTION (strong feeling) here, resolving only when I  couldn’t solve 18d.

Even then, I wasn’t sure about design = MOTIVE. The definition of MOTIVE is “a reason for doing something“.

You have to read as far as the seventh definition of ‘design’ in Collins Online to find “a general plan or intention that someone has in their mind when they are doing something” – not convinced that an intention to do something is quite the same as a reason for doing something…

PLEASANT – PEASANT (rustic) contains L{ake}

This is “rustic” as a noun, and this is a chestnut, along with PEASANT/PHEASANT

Uncouth person grabbing tail of skittish bird (8) from QC 2572

AVA Gardner, the film actress and AVATAR, the 2009 film
