quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2702 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Get rid of outdated alcoholic drink (4)
quick-cryptic.definition: get rid of / outdated alcoholic drink
quick-cryptic.solution: SACK – double definition. SACK was (the word has fallen out of general use, hence “outdated”) a generic name for a variety of fortified, sweet white wines from Spain or the Canaries, much beloved of Sir John Falstaff. Its origin is not clear; the theory I find most convincing is that it comes from the Spanish verb sacar (to draw down, as from a cask – so wines which had been drawn from their casks were sacas).
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2683 by Hurley – setter wars – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.solution:
MAESTRO – Anagram [refined] of EAR MOST.

I didn’t distinguish myself by reading “Conductor” but thinking “Composer”. So I was running through composer’s names for a while.

Think this might be a breezeblock for one or two – very cunning setter, very cunning!

quick-cryptic.clue: Meeting, something exciting for prisoners? (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
POWWOW – POW (prisoners, specifically prisoners of war) + WOW (expression of excitement).

The word Powwow is an American First Nation word and traditionally meant an important social gathering for ceremonial and celebratory purposes.  I am not quite sure how it got its modern colloquial meeting (in British English at least) of an informal business meeting to discuss something important, which seems some way from the word’s original meaning and cultural significance.

quick-cryptic.clue: Fashionable before Windy City (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
CHICAGO – CHIC (fashionable) + AGO (before).

Contrary to popular belief, Chicago is not the windiest city in the United States, or even in the top ten.  Instead, the nickname seems to have come from a newspaper reporter named Charles A Dana, who commented in 1893 that the city’s politicians were “full of wind, full of hot air”.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2727 by Lupa – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.solution: DUET – DUE (“expected”) + T (“time”).

quick-cryptic.solution: SCOOP – Double definition.

A word you only ever see preceded by “filthy”.  Cash may seem a fairly loose definition but it’s becoming associated more and more with illicit activities.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2805 by Mara – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Lessons a rep arranged for colleague in shop? (11)
quick-cryptic.solution: SALESPERSON – (lessons a rep)* [arranged].
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2654 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Film director in story by composer (9)
quick-cryptic.solution:
SPIELBERG – SPIEL (story) + BERG (composer).

Alban Berg (1885-1935) was an Austrian composer and a leading member of the Second Viennese School.  He is considered by many to be one of the most important composers of the early 20th century and even has an asteroid named after him (4528 Berg, discovered in 1983).  But even so, I would venture to suggest that more of our solvers will have heard of Steven Spielberg than him – which fact might add to the debate over whether living people are well enough known.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic no 2781 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Place of great beauty, old and new, exotic, welcoming King (10)
quick-cryptic.solution: WONDERLAND – anagram (‘exotic’) of OLD AND NEW with R for King inserted
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2732 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Try removing odd bits of radium (3)
quick-cryptic.solution: AIM – {r}a{d}i{u}m
quick-cryptic.title: QC 2771 by Alex – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Part of simple sum in school exam (6-4)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ELEVEN-PLUS – “Eleven plus three” (or any other number) is a simple sum, so “eleven plus” is “part of a simple sum”.

The “school exam” refers to a test given to children at age 11 or 12 to determine where they will go for secondary education. It was compulsory for all in the past (my parents took it) and survives – at least in spirit – in the entrance examinations for some grammar schools.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2646 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: The banger Len moved somewhere in East London (7,5)
quick-cryptic.solution: BETHNAL GREEN – Anagram [moved] of THE BANGER LEN.

quick-cryptic.clue: To Greeks at first a Roman habit (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: TOGA – TO + G (Greeks “at first”) + A
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2733 by Wurm – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Some say she barely managed to change her husband’s mind (4,6)
quick-cryptic.definition: some say she barely managed to change her husband’s mind
quick-cryptic.solution:
LADY GODIVA – Cryptic def

I don’t think I ever knew whether Lady G was a figure from history, fiction or mythology.  Seems to be a bit of each.

But of course we’re all familiar with the story of the woman riding naked through the town as a form of protest against her hubby’s tax regime.  One chap named Tom disobeyed the order to stay inside and draw the blinds, and that’s where we get the term Peeping Tom.

Hard to blame Tom, I reckon we’d all have been a bit curious.  Just glad we were spared the term Peeping Galspray.

quick-cryptic.solution: LEAVE – Double def, and a chestnut

I was surprised to see “costly” as part of the definition. It’s much cheaper than silk, and still cheaper than wool or linen.

“Oily” is an adjective, and I’m not convinced of an adjectival use of “fat” that matches. “Fatty”, sure, but “fat”?

I wonder if I will be alone in finding this a little unkind – not all family units with one parent are the result of a broken relationship, as some are planned from the start and others the result of the early death of a partner.  And I don’t think the question mark really rescues the clue.

NICKER is also dated slang for a pound, often used for higher numbers such as “fify nicker”. OED has “origin unknown”

Definition by example indicated by ‘perhaps’

quick-cryptic.clue: US president supportive of daughter (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: FORD – FOR for “supportive of” + D for “daughter”. Gerald FORD was the 38th President of the United States from 1974 to 1977. I’d barely heard of the guy before I started doing crosswords; now I write him in without a second thought. (In checking his dates for the blog I learned he was very lucky to be alive, since a member of the Manson Clan tried to shoot him at point blank range during a walkabout. Fortunately she didn’t understand how the gun worked and there was no bullet in the chamber, or he’d have had it.)

quick-cryptic.solution:

I think this is a bit of a loose clue: there’s no real indication that ONE is part of the anagrist.

edit: thanks to Kevin for pointing out that the parsing should be ‘anagram [unusual] of NAME, + ONE’.

I got this right on paper and then switched the M and the last N when submitting online. Rats.

quick-cryptic.clue: Test bomb underneath rising chopper (7)
quick-cryptic.solution:
EXAMINE – MINE (bomb) after (ie underneath, as this is a down clue) EXA (axe, ie chopper, reversed, ie rising).

Mines and bombs are not identical: for the military the difference is that a mine is often concealed (eg under the surface of either the ground or the sea) and left until it is triggered by someone or something disturbing it, whereas a bomb is often projected towards the enemy and explodes on impact. But for us non-military types they are close enough to be counted as synonyms.

Another Chestnut. It’s not a particularly big town, or common girls name. Though with the current craze for weird names it wouldn’t surprise me if there are girls being named after lots of French towns

In 2021, Nancy ranked 878th in popularity for girls’ names in the United States. And Paris is at 252.

Cryptic, ‘lot’ being another word for ‘fortune’.

Market research company MORI (Market and Opinion Research International) was founded in 1969 and merged with Ipsos in 2005 to become Ipsos MORI. In 2022, the company was rebranded to simply Ipsos.

Brilliant anagram, so smooth I didn’t see it at first. “certain” often means “sure” which is a handy set of letters. And “Foreign Pastor” contains 13 letters with a helpful “-ing” in there. Plenty of scope for misdirection here.

quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2719 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: In the same place I stay overlooking Malta’s capital (6)
quick-cryptic.solution:
IBIDEM – I BIDE (I stay) + M (Malta’s capital, ie first letter of Malta – and as it happens, the only capital letter in the word as it is written here).

Ibidem is the Latin word for “in the same place”, so a very straightforward clue, even if the word is not widely used, and classical scholars will have had no problem here.  Most of the rest of us will be much more familiar with its abbreviation ibid, used repeatedly in footnotes and references in learned papers and the like to refer one back to a previous reference.

quick-cryptic.solution:
PSALM – S (son) in PALM (part of hand)

A PSALM is a “sacred poem or song,” especially one expressing praise and thanksgiving. Originally, in both Latin psalmus and Greek psalmos, the meaning was “performance on stringed instrument; a plucking of the harp”.

After some hesitation, the pedantic PS– spelling has prevailed in English, as it has in many neighbouring languages (German, French, etc.), but English is almost alone in not pronouncing the P–….
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2700 by Pedro – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Cross after minor operation brought about complaint (8)
quick-cryptic.solution:
SMALLPOX – SMALL (minor) + PO [OP (operation) reversed (brought about)] + X (cross)

Again, a number of simple enough elements combined to make a not-so-simple clue.

NHO. Bay rum: It’s a type of cologne and aftershave lotion. They say that during the Prohibition era it was reportedly consumed as a beverage due to its high alcohol content (over 50%).

Clothes switches from a noun in the surface to a verb in the wordplay.

quick-cryptic.solution:
ORGAN – OR (in preference to) + G (grand) + A + N (new)

I’m having trouble making OR = “in preference to”.

I guess it’s implicit in offers such as “tea or coffee?” or “soup or salad?” but is that enough?  Maybe it is.  Or maybe I’m completely missing the point.

One for the Ecclesiastic vestments fans to go with COPE, STOLE and ALB. All crossword staples. It’s that red hat thing that cardinals wear, although they can be in other colours for lower ranks.

Not to be confused by Bond’s gun, the Beretta.

If this was a NHO, then Beritta was a good guess, as both the I and E were unchecked.

quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2719 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Maybe stag recruits engineer and doctor for festive time (8)
quick-cryptic.solution:
DECEMBER – DEER (‘Maybe stag’) contains (‘recruits’) CE (‘engineer’) and MB (‘doctor’)

I think the ‘festive time’ is meant to include Advent as well as Christmas.

We had CE for civil engineer in a crossword not a million miles from here very recently. CE also comes up in the dictionaries and search engines as an abbreviation for a chief or chemical engineer. According to Wikipedia, “CEng” refers to a chartered engineer, an engineer registered in the UK with the Engineering Council who has both postgraduate qualifications and significant practical experience; I couldn’t find anywhere that CE can be applied in this context as well.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2747 by Breadman – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Elastic  sort of brick? (9)
quick-cryptic.solution:
STRETCHER – Another one I’m calling a double definition.

A stretcher in brickwork is a brick laid so that its long narrow face is visible, rather than its short narrow face or the top or bottom. If you think of the classic 8-spot Lego piece, it is laid as a stretcher when the long smooth side is visible. For some reason I knew this: it’s probably come up in a crossword before.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic No 2778 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Upright type, member of an empire (5)
quick-cryptic.solution:
ROMAN – Double def

Excellent and COD. Usually “type” in a clue is an attribute or a person, so upright type might be “saint”, or “paragon”. But this time type means what is now usually called a font.

And Roman font like this has very upright letters.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2639 by Izetti – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.solution: BRACELET – BRACE (two, a couple) + LET (permitted), with the charmed circle being a charm bracelet, a bracelet which has little charms, often silver, attached to it.

quick-cryptic.solution:

The mid-15th century meaning of STOVE in English was “heated room“. The more modern meaning of “vessel in which heat radiates from a burning fuel for warming a room or cooking” is from 1610s.

A word coined as recently as 1995, which for Crosswordland is barely yesterday, despite the fact that young women having fun have always existed – 100 years ago they were called flappers.

There are at least two Salems in the US: one was the site of the witch trials featured in The Crucible, and the other one I know of is the state capital of Oregon. Apologies if you live in another Salem.

quick-cryptic.solution:
CUTTING
Two meanings

quick-cryptic.solution: MINARET – our second &Lit, and my COD in a packed field. A MINARET is the tall, slim tower on a mosque from which the muezzin calls the faithful to prayer – thus a place from there is an “elevated religious calling”. Very good indeed, bravo.

Colloquial use of FISHY for suspicious goes back to the mid 1800s. Not clear where it comes from. I would guess from the notion of “slipperiness,” or of giving off a bad smell.

quick-cryptic.solution: WALDORF SALAD – anagram (prepared) of DISH WAS FOR LAD, with the definition referring back to the word DISH. Yum. Although it’s been a while since I’ve had one. Edit: that would of course be a WISHDORF SALAD (a revolting thing indeed); this is an anagram (prepared) of WAS FOR LAD, with “another” LAD on the end.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2749 by Asp – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Issue US magazine promoted (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: EMIT – TIME (US magazine) reversed (promoted)

quick-cryptic.solution: INSTALLATION – IN + ALL (everyone) “enters” STATION (railway property)

quick-cryptic.clue: Heavy defeat — manager finally dismissed (4)
quick-cryptic.solution: ROUT – Last letter of manageR, OUT (dismissed in cricket).
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2750 by Hurley – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: In dispute, what’s needed for a 3? (2,5)
quick-cryptic.definition: in dispute / what’s needed for a 3
quick-cryptic.solution:
AT ISSUE – A double definition, or a definition with a cryptic hint? Either way, the second meaning is A TISSUE, which is needed for a sneeze: the answer to 3d is ATISHOO.

It always seems to be the case that when a clue refers to the answer to another clue, I always find the referring clue first.
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2562 by Teazel – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Turning tail, sailor is a traitor (3)

The term “paste” in jewelry refers to the paste-like mixture used in the manufacturing process. The components of the mixture are combined wet to ensure thorough and even distribution

AND SO ON – A (‘A’) N (‘new’) D (‘day’) SOON (‘before long’)

I’d first thought ‘before’ was a positional indicator.
quick-cryptic.title: Quick Cryptic 2585 by Jalna – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.solution: WED — WE (you and I) + the last letter of (… in the end) decideD

quick-cryptic.solution: RAIDER – RIDER (horseman) contains A

quick-cryptic.solution: MOCK – double definition

quick-cryptic.clue: Military detachment touring Finland’s capital, needing more exercise (5)
quick-cryptic.solution: UNFIT – First letter of Finland [Finland’s capital] in UNIT (military detachment).
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2762 by Jimmy – Times for The Times

quick-cryptic.clue: Artist profits, having place for market in London (12)
quick-cryptic.solution:
GAINSBOROUGH – GAINS (profits) BOROUGH (place for market in London)

I was well and truly foxed, looking at the wrong end of the stick here, thinking that the answer was one of the London markets – it was frustrating me that I couldn’t remember some of their names!

Borough market should, of course, be familiar to any of you who met at The George on the 14th, or who takes part in the annual crossword competition at the nearby News Building by London Bridge station.

Apart from the neat misdirection, I’m not really sure what ‘having’ is doing in the clue other than to improve the surface. The words ‘place for’ also seem superfluous. Perhaps ‘Artist profits at London market (12)‘ would be too easy and so, the rest is deliberate bumfuzzling…
quick-cryptic.title: Times Quick Cryptic No 2712 by Jalna – Times for The Times

My COD. Loved the surface. Deadly Derek Underwood in 1972 comes to mind; the conspiracy theory is that it was a doctored pitch, but I’m sure that’s just me. While we’re at it, let’s not even mention 1981 at the same ground.

quick-cryptic.solution: REEL – double definition. I assumed the latter to be some noisy instrument I was unaware of, but no, Chambers defines it as a “cylinder, drum, spool, bobbin or frame on which thread, fishing-line, wire, cables, photographic film, etc may be wound.”  Aah yes, duh! That makes more sense.

DEDUCIBLE
Anagram [in new way] of CLUED BIDE

The Severn is indeed the UK’s longest river. Although (say) seven children is not a small number of children to have, I think “small number” for seven is OK, as numbers go on for ever and seven is, well, the eighth smallest natural number.

quick-cryptic.solution: NUT – TUN (barrel) reversed -> NUT. All nuts are fruits (unless they go on a bolt or sit on top of your neck or are crazy people or an en or a small lump of coal… etc), but not all fruits are nuts, although a fruitcake can be one even though he/she doesn’t have a shell. [Enough! Ed]. I’ll get my coat.

No shortage of exclamations today. With 14a, we have ‘Good heavens!’, DEAR ME, ‘My’ and COR.

Used for cutting with the grain.  Across the grain you’ll want a crosscut saw of some description.  Measure twice, cut once.  That’s the entirety of my woodworking knowledge.

mephisto.solution: PAPE – P + APE.   Yes P is a valid abbreviation for pastor.   Pape referred to a particular bishop, according to Chambers.

monthly-club-special.clue: Rating Angus’s one grand? No longer paying (6)
monthly-club-special.solution: ABYING – AB (Able-bodied seaman; rating) YIN (Scottish for one) G (grand). “No longer” indicates the word is archaic.

monthly-club-special.solution: EPITRITES – PI (irrational number; 3.1415926535…) TRITE (banal) in ES (French for (you singular) are; archaically art in English… as we all know from crosswords).

monthly-club-special.clue: Half of Kazaks making a return in exchange for Muslim tax (5)
monthly-club-special.solution: ZAKAT – First half of KAZ{aks} reversed -> ZAK, AT (in exchange for).
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 280 – Nov 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Legal expert has an interrogation shortened under uneducated Australian bloke (7)
monthly-club-special.solution: ALFAQUI – ALF (uneducated Australian bloke) A QUI{z} (interrogation) [shortened].

monthly-club-special.clue: Pared-down Damnation of Faust with intermissions (2-3)
monthly-club-special.solution: ON-OFF – Hidden in DamnatiON OF Faust.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 273 – April 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: From sister in France, taking against English jobless? (9)
monthly-club-special.solution: DESOEUVRE – DE (from in French), V (against) in SOEUR (sister in French), E (English).
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 275 – June 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Landing vehicle from US to carry old woman westwards (6)
monthly-club-special.solution: AMTRAC – CART (carry) MA (old woman) all reversed -> AMTRAC.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 274 – May 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Straight ticket without mark of approval stops man in the lead (6)
monthly-club-special.solution: HETERO – {tick}ET without the TICK (mark of approval), in HERO (man in the lead). Clever, but I’m not sure I understand the surface meaning.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 20279 – December 2023 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Point raised in mostly overemotional gathering by a Pole? (7)
monthly-club-special.solution: ICEPACK – CAPE (point) [raised] -> PACE, in ICK{y} (overemotional) [mostly].
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special 271 – Feb 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Old temple: that’s found empty, and pub, the first now the last one (8)
monthly-club-special.solution: TEOCALLI –T{empl}E (that) [found empty], LOCAL (pub) with first letter moved to the end [the first now the last] -> OCALL, I (one). “That” means use TEMPLE in the wordplay as well as the definition, so the word temple isn’t doing double duty.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 272 – March 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Conservative in wing of building greeting emissary (5)
monthly-club-special.solution: ELCHI – C (conservative) in EL (L-shaped wing of a building), HI (greeting). A Turkish ambassador.

monthly-club-special.clue: Service manual essential to plan my holiday’s return (6)
monthly-club-special.solution: HYMNAL – Reverse hidden in pLAN MY Holiday
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 278 – September 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Vessel filled with claret wine US lawman knocked back to begin with (8)
monthly-club-special.solution: PRAECAVA – ERAP (US lawman) [knocked back] -> PRAE, CAVA (wine). The superior vena cava, the vein carrying blood from the head, arms and thorax. “Vessel filled with claret”. Nice one!
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 279 – October 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Incompetent person’s decline in ecological role, with no end in sight (7)
monthly-club-special.solution: NEBBICH – EBB (decline) in NICH{e} (ecological role) [with no end in sight].
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 20279 – December 2023 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: A gazelle, a second, then 3600 of them (4)
monthly-club-special.solution: MOHR – MO (a second), HR (hour; 3600 seconds).
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 275 – June 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: I’m very annoyed the man’s going to cheat Society, collecting billions (5,5)
monthly-club-special.solution: HELLS BELLS – HE’LL (the man’s going to), B (billions) in SELL (cheat), S (society). Great surface.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 20279 – December 2023 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: No longer know which exam, informally (7)
monthly-club-special.solution: WOTTEST – WOT TEST (which exam, informally). Ho ho.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 274 – May 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Presumably the person in charge of steak for large lizard (10)
monthly-club-special.solution: CHUCKWALLA – Double definition, the first a cryptic hint referring to a WALLA (person in charge) of CHUCK (a cut of steak). Lovely word.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 20279 – December 2023 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: In Kentucky, approved flag with height variable shows dandelion (3-6)

monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 280 – Nov 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Ass Jack runs out of stuff for cheese (6)
monthly-club-special.solution: JENNET – J (Jack), {r}ENNET (stuff for cheese) without the R (runs).
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 274 – May 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Customary feature of acoustic set? (5)
monthly-club-special.solution: NOMIC – An acoustic set would have NO MIC.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 278 – September 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 276 – July 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Synagogue cantors mostly vague on the soul, without foundation (7)
monthly-club-special.solution: HAZANIM – HAZ{y} (vague) [mostly] ANIM{a} (soul) without the last latter.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 276 – July 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Bone up incomplete final part in radio series (3)
monthly-club-special.solution: LUZ – ZUL{u} (last letter in the phonetic alphabet; final part in radio series), [incomplete], [up] -> LUZ.

monthly-club-special.clue: See European strong guys weep, expressing right strength of feeling (9)
monthly-club-special.solution: VEHEMENCY – V (videlicet; see) E (European) HE MEN (strong guys) C{r}Y (weep) without the R (right).
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 280 – Nov 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: What Scot uses before bowing to king, swallowing drugs from the east (5)
monthly-club-special.solution: ROSET – ES (drugs) in TO R (rex; king) all reversed -> ROSET, a Scottish name for ROSIN, used by a string player on their bow.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 277 – August 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Hungry Shakespearean actor wants this sausage coated with pecan (6)
monthly-club-special.solution: KISHKE – Good grief! I’m not sure how I managed to work this one out! It’s PECKISH (hungry) KEAN (Shakespearean actor; this one) with PECAN outside the answer, KISHKE. Nope I hadn’t heard of him. Had you?
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special 271 – Feb 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Counterfeiter penning Slavic novel, article and set of Victorian letters (4,9)
monthly-club-special.solution: FORS CLAVIGERA – (slavic)* [novel] in FORGER (counterfeiter) A (article). Wonderfully obscure. The name given by John Ruskin to a series of letters addressed to British workmen during the 1870s. They were published in the form of pamphlets. The letters formed part of Ruskin’s interest in moral intervention in the social issues of the day on the model of his mentor Thomas Carlyle.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 279 – October 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: When returning, book hotel area in coastal plain (6)
monthly-club-special.solution: SABKHA – AS (when) returning -> SA, BK (book) H (hotel in the phonetic alphabet) A (area).
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 276 – July 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Digestive processes disrupted in stomach if icy (14)
monthly-club-special.solution: CHYMIFICATIONS – (in stomach if icy)* [disrupted].
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 273 – April 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Recalled emotional problem but not an antique that reeks (4)
monthly-club-special.solution: PUGH – An old spelling of POOH. H{an}GUP (emotional problem) reversed and without the AN.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 275 – June 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Coin once passed on, behold sent back (4)
monthly-club-special.solution: OBOL – OB (obit; passed on) LO (behold) [sent back] -> OL.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 272 – March 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Means to catch school members provoking people by golf clubs (8-6)
monthly-club-special.solution: TROLLING-SPOONS – TROLLING (provoking people online) SPOONS (the old clubs equivalent to a modern fairway wood).
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 277 – August 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Smallest state twice catching very American smuggler involves scene that can make you smile (8,6)
monthly-club-special.solution: RISORIUS MUSCLE – SO (very) in RI (Rhode Island; smallest state in USA) RI [twice], US (American), SC (scene) in MULE (smuggler). Phew. Very Ikean.
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 273 – April 2024 – Times for The Times

monthly-club-special.clue: Scooter circling awfully inert learner in the evening (11)
monthly-club-special.solution: VESPERTINAL – (inert)* [awfully] in VESPA (scooter), L (learner).
monthly-club-special.title: Monthly Club Special No 277 – August 2024 – Times for The Times

ESCUDOS – anagram, broken, of US CODES.
The currency of Chile – that sort of capital!

DUOMO
DUO, MO.
 It’s approximately just the Italian equivalent of “cathedral”, apparently.

HOT CHOCOLATE – anagram (bad) of TOOTHACHE containing (drinking) COL (most of COLA)
Another “sweet drink”, that is.

weekend-daily-cryptics.clue: Food hopper where a chip might go? (4-2-3-4)
weekend-daily-cryptics.solution: TOAD-IN-THE-HOLE    TOAD, “hopper” + IN THE HOLE, “where a chip might go?”—“chip” here being short for a “chip shot” in golf
weekend-daily-cryptics.title: Sunday Times Cryptic No 5107 — PlayTime – Times for The Times

weekend-daily-cryptics.clue: A fan of the dentist? (9)
weekend-daily-cryptics.solution: EXTRACTOR    DD   An EXTRACTOR (or “extraction”) fan is “used in kitchens, bathrooms, workshops, etc, to remove stale air or fumes” (Collins).   …The dentist I was taken to as a child should have had EXTRACTOR as an official title. I wasn’t a fan!

weekend-daily-cryptics.clue: Have a host, perhaps, promoting posh European’s noble deed (4,5)
weekend-daily-cryptics.solution: BEAU GESTE – BE A GUEST (have a host, perhaps: ho ho!), promoting U one place earlier in the word, then E (European).
weekend-daily-cryptics.title: Times Cryptic 28806 – Sat, 6 Jan 2024. Fireworks now. – Times for The Times

weekend-daily-cryptics.clue: Man wants a kiss first as a rule(5)

DOSS DOWN – DO + SS (leads to Some Sleep) DOWN.
I suppose “down” as a noun can mean “deprivation”.
On edit: as Peter W explains in his comment, D is the “lead” to Deprivation, then OWN is “have”.

weekend-daily-cryptics.title: Sunday Times Cryptic No 5123 by David McLean — Stumped? In a pickle? – Times for The Times

weekend-daily-cryptics.title: Times Cryptic 28848 – Sat, 24 Feb 2024. Flying, while flying. – Times for The Times

weekend-daily-cryptics.title: Times Cryptic 29052 – Saturday, 19 October 2024. Fun on the run. – Times for The Times

weekend-daily-cryptics.clue: Insects foremost in carrying disease (8)
weekend-daily-cryptics.solution: CRICKETS    Carrying + RICKETS, “disease”   …As it happened, in the week before this puzzle came out, I learned this Fun Fact: « Crickets are cold-blooded and take on the temperature of their surroundings. In 1897, a scientist named Amos Dolbear published an article titled “The Cricket as a Thermometer” that noted the correlation between the ambient temperature and the rate at which crickets chirp. The insects’ muscles contract to produce chirping based on chemical reactions. The warmer the temperature, the easier the cricket’s muscles activate, so the chirps increase.… The formula expressed in that article became known as Dolbear’s Law. It’s surprisingly simple: To Convert Cricket Chirps to Degrees Fahrenheit: Just count the number of chirps in 14 seconds, then add 40 to get the temperature. To Convert Cricket Chirps to Degrees Celsius: Count the number of chirps in 25 seconds, divide by 3, then add 4 to get the temperature. » From an article at almanac.com.

weekend-daily-cryptics.solution: OPINE    Hidden   The closest OPINE comes to “Volunteer” in dictionaries is in the latter’s definition as “to say, tell, or communicate voluntarily.” But the idiom “volunteer an opinion” is heard frequently enough—and an opinion is indeed often offered without its being asked for (or even welcome!).  We’ve seen the terms equated in these puzzles before, and Thesaurus.com be damned!

weekend-daily-cryptics.clue: People, being hot, just now dressing (7)
weekend-daily-cryptics.solution: INHABIT    IN, “hot, just now” + HABIT, “dressing”   Edit: I am now informed that my first parsing, IN (H) A BIT, was the intended one, with the phrase draped over H meaning “just now”—which it doesn’t in any of our standard sources.   …I changed that about an hour before the blog went live, before rushing off to a friend’s birthday gathering. I’ve never heard of the dictionary that editor Biddlecombe mentions, and have never heard IN A BIT used in that way.  Indeed, it seems a loss to the language if IN A BIT and “just now” are no longer to mean different things.

weekend-daily-cryptics.solution: IN OFFICE    IN[-]OFF, “at table, foul” + ICE, “dessert”   …Edited! I didn’t get the snooker reference, pointed out below. Purely for comic relief, my original note follows: Collins online has only an entry for “at table” from an American dictionary, whereas the American resource Merriam-Webster lists it as “British  | sitting at a table and eating a meal.” IN often means “at home,” which might be where one is most commonly “at table”—but, then again, might not.   …I couldn’t find a source that ties the two ideas any closer together, though I fully expected to (and to not have to gloss this at such length).

jumbo-cryptic.clue: Bring in vino in part of house for this activity? (4,7)
jumbo-cryptic.solution:
WINE TASTING
NET (bring in – earn after tax) + ASTI (Italian vino) contained by [in] WING (part of house). The definition is reflexive.
jumbo-cryptic.title: Times Cryptic Jumbo 1669 20/04/2024 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Make move on royal with crush on Charley Fortnum? (8,6)
everything-else.solution: HONORARY CONSUL – Novel by Graham Greene with Charles Fortnum in the title role. Anagram (make move) of ON ROYAL ON CRUSH.
everything-else.title: Times Literary Cryptic Jumbo No 1 Monday 14 October 2024 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: A large fish actor gives the producer of Campion (9)
everything-else.solution: ALLINGHAM – A plus L[arge] plus LING (fish) plus HAM (actor). Margery Allingham created the gentleman sleuth Albert Campion.
everything-else.title: Times Literary Cryptic Jumbo No 1 Monday 14 October 2024 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Runner pursuing mate is womanising Post Office ‘worker’ (8)
everything-else.solution: CHINASKI – Henry, the creation and alter ego of Charles Bukovsky, succinctly described. SKI for runner after CHINA for mate. (CRS).
everything-else.title: Times Literary Cryptic Jumbo No 1 Monday 14 October 2024 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Polemic playwright bound to be heard by some on radio (4)
everything-else.solution: SHAW – George Bernard, of course, more or less a homophone of SURE, bound to be.
everything-else.title: Times Literary Cryptic Jumbo No 1 Monday 14 October 2024 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Large snake almost swallowing a pointy object? (5,3)
everything-else.title: Sign of The Times Cryptic No 1 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Beginnings of citywide low emissions area not without mishap (5)
everything-else.solution: CLEAN – starting letters of C[itywide] L[ow] E[missions] A[rea] N[ot]
everything-else.title: Year in Review News Cryptic 2023 – Times for The Times

everything-else.solution:
FIREBRAND – F1 REBRAND

When first looking at this one, I had no idea what was going on, so skipped on quickly. By the time I came back to it, I had every checking letter, and FIREBRAND immediately came to mind, so I entered it without remembering any element of the clue, confident that nothing else would fit F?R?B?A?D. Having written it, I read the first word of the clue again, and was happy the definition matched.
everything-else.title: Times Crossword Championship 2024 – Think literally, not laterally – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Eagles flying round northern birthplace of TikToker Khaby Lame (7)
everything-else.title: Sign of The Times Cryptic No 1 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Speaking honestly, I came first and still I get oddly ignored (1,4,3)
everything-else.solution: I WONT LIE – I  WON (came first) and alternate letters (even numbered) of sTiLl I gEt.
everything-else.title: Sign of The Times Cryptic No 1 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Hacker from Chiba seen in court action (4)
everything-else.solution: CASE – From William Gibson’s Neuromancer, Henry Dorsett Case is a low-level hustler in Chiba city Japan and sometime computer hacker.
everything-else.title: Times Literary Cryptic Jumbo No 1 Monday 14 October 2024 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Crablike motion of Labour leader moving right in drift (5)
everything-else.solution: SIDLE – SLIDE with the L moved to the right.
everything-else.title: Year in Review News Cryptic 2023 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Golden gong given to uncultivated English epigrammatist (5,5)
everything-else.solution: OSCAR WILDE – The golden gong is an OSCAR, uncultivated is WILD, add E[nglish]. Oscar Fingal O’Fflahertie Wills Wilde, you might guess, was not English!
everything-else.title: Times Literary Cryptic Jumbo No 1 Monday 14 October 2024 – Times for The Times
Sign of The Times Cryptic No 1 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Some cry, distraught about a tree (8)
everything-else.solution: SYCAMORE – Anagram of SOME CRY around A.
everything-else.title: Year in Review News Cryptic 2023 – Times for The Times

everything-else.clue: Where you might see Anton Du Beke chew on cold fare (5,5)
everything-else.definition: where you might see anton du beke / anton du beke
everything-else.solution: DANCE FLOOR – “Strictly” pro, now judge, still appears on this anagram (chew) of ON COLD FARE.
everything-else.title: Times Literary Cryptic Jumbo No 1 Monday 14 October 2024 – Times for The Times
